values:
CHD - possibly useful DARE abstracts.

http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/978212.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/988106.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/988106.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/971454.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/975328.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/978187.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/20008620.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/20008000.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/20018403.htm
http://nhscrd.york.ac.uk/online/dare/20028051.htm

Draft CHD subject search summary.

Quite a lot of worthwhile stuff on Dare that can go on when a protocol has been devised. Subject area is very broad; again, large overlap with MI, arteriosclerosis and stroke. Most of the major guidelines are on already. Was quite selective about what material went on - left off some of the more minor non-UK guidelines.

Now on congenital heart defects. http://www.acr.org/cgi-bin/fr?tmpl:appcrit,pdf:0067-72_suspected_congenital_heart_disease-ac.pdf - good document, but RMS won't accept URL.

URL Cleanup Pre-Hospital Guidelines 2002 For Use In UK Ambulance Services http://www.warwickuniversity.nhs.uk Supplementary URL - no longer valid, and cannot trace. 01/04/04 - A Randomised Controlled Trial To Compare A Nurse Practitioner To Medical Staff In The Preparation Of Patients For Diagnostic Cardiac Catheterisation: The Study Of Nursing Intervention In Practice (SNIP) http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WVB-4C7VM3G-1T1&_user=122868&_coverDate=04%2F26%2F2004&_alid=172601383&_rdoc=6&_fmt=summary&_orig=search&_cdi=7098&_sort=d&_docanchor=&_acct=C000010083&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=122868&md5= URL will not fit into Cardex. Full URL listed in abstract of Cardex, which has been switched to draft. Nurse-run Clinics In Primary Care Increased Secondary Prevention In Coronary Artery Disease http://www.acponline.org/journals/acpjc/mayjun99/campbell.htm ACP journals club requires subscription in order to be able to view articles. This may have been the problem. 3rd European Conference on: Management of Coronary Heart Disease http://www.bcs.com/cgi-bin/course.cgi?show=114&b=3 No longer exists on site. Delete? Thrombolysis : Questions And Answers http://www.nhs.uk/syndication/showart.asp?DB=NewsTable&ID=558 No longer exists on site. Delete? 01/05/04 - Non-ST-Elevation Acute Coronary Syndrome In The Elderly: Treatment Strategies And 30-day Outcome http://www2.us.elsevierhealth.com/scripts/om.dll/serve?action=searchDB&searchDBfor=art&artType=abs&id=as0002870303008809&nav=abs Now works perfectly. Momentary blip? A Nurse-run Program For Congestive Heart Failure Reduced Time To Hospital Readmission http://www.acponline.org/journals/acpjc/mayjun99/cline.htm ACP journals club requires subscription in order to be able to view articles. This may have been the problem. Coronary Artery Stents : A Rapid Systematic Review And Economic Evaluation http://www.nice.org.uk/Docref.asp?d=76205 Working fine. Another blip? The Misuse Of Drugs (Amendment) (No. 3) Regulations 2003 http://www.hmso.gov.uk/si/si2003/20032429.htm Again, absolutely fine. Primary Care Clinical Update ICC http://www.fbpcs.org.uk/main.htm Site does not exist. 8th World Congress of Echocardiography and Vascular Ultrasound http://www.bcs.com/cgi-bin/course.cgi?show=146&b=3 Link exists on bcs website, which suggests page is temporarily down. Check again later. Indexing Indexing for rest of week: Cardiac Networks, Treatment Notes, Cochrane VASC reviews. Start from back-end of alphabet and work up to L or so.

<lj-cut text="See below">
Chest pain - 11-15/05/04
Summary:
Not much available on this topic. Suspect this is because much of it falls under other, more specific condition categories such as angina and MI. Much of the available literature also relates to non-cardiac chest pain. As usual, I suspect that the ACP journals might yield useful results. However, such a generalised search term was a bit confusing to the indexer, which probably didn't help. Two quick queries: http://www.acr.org/cgi-bin/fr?tmpl:appcrit,pdf:0079-84_acute_chest_pain_no_evidence_mi_ac.pdf relates to chest pain, not entirely or even principally to cardiovascular conditions, and http://144.32.150.197/scripts/WEBC.EXE/nhscrd/expand?saan=0000280631 - not sure how to index DARE abstracts.



Coronary Heart Disease, searching on CHD and CAD

AHRQ - Still down.
CMA - now ineligible to access database.

NGC
http://www.ahrq.gov/clinic/uspstf/uspsacad.htm - down but possibly useful

NeLH Guideline Database
http://www.prodigy.nhs.uk/guidance.asp?gt=CHD%20risk%20-%20identify%20and%20manage - won't load.

NZGG

NLM Health Services

Primary Care Clinical Practice Guidelines

SIGN

ARIF

Cochrane
Exercise-based rehabilitation for coronary heart disease
Percutaneous transluminal rotational atherectomy for coronary artery disease
Reduced or modified dietary fat for preventing cardiovascular disease
Smoking cessation for the secondary prevention of coronary heart disease

EHCB

EM

HTA database

HTApubs

NICE
http://www.nice.org.uk/pdf/Guidance_GLYCOPROTNS.pdf
To do.

Safest to put it here as well. Things to do on Tuesday:

Check Lesley's indexing of Cochrane and pay attention to format for dates. Tweak the Hypertension documents accordingly.

When indexing Clinical Evidence, try and keep it to 5 indexing terms and 5 MeSH headings each as per your putative protocol.

CMA looks as though it might have some handy stuff on Chest Pain.

BHF Factfile 8/99 

Joint British Recommendations On Prevention Of Coronary Heart Disease In Clinical Practice (Part 1) Lifestyle And Therapeutic Targets For Secondary And Primary Prevention.
British Heart Foundation
http://www.bhf.org.uk/professionals/uploaded/aug99.pdf

http://www.bhf.org.uk/professionals/uploaded/bhf_factfile_september1999_updated.pdf
Part 2.

British Heart Foundation factfile 8-1999. This fact sheet deals with the targets set by the British Cardiac Society, British Hyperlipidaemia Association, British Hypertension Society and British Diabetic Association for secondary and primary prevention of coronary heart disease. Targets are suggested for lifestyle, medication and screening. Part 1 of 2.

Coronary Heart Disease
Prevention
Causes and Risk Factors
Hypertension

Abstract: 

This Clinical Evidence topic addresses the following questions:

i) Which treatments improve outcomes in acute myocardial infarction? 
ii) Which treatments improve outcomes for cardiogenic shock after acute myocardial infarction? 

Topic search date: February 2003.

Clinical Evidence is freely available to NHS staff, patients and the public in England through the National electronic Library for Health. No password is needed:
http://www.nelh.nhs.uk/clinical_evidence.asp 
Clinical Evidence is also available on a subscription basis.

CVDSL and MeSH indexing as normal.

Broad overlap in this area with Myocardial Infarction. In general, very few hits retrieved and most of those amounted to peripheral references to rescuscitation. Again, access to ACP, Harcourt and the BMJ 'evidence-based' series may have proved helpful. Since the phrase 'cardiac arrest' sees more general use, this will be the next search term.

Term itself barely if ever coming up in hits on various databases. Even relevant documents temd to fit better under other subject headings ie cholesterol lowering, lipids management, CHD. This may have to do with a lack of knowledge on my part. Got as far as Cochrane.

As expected, the overlap between this search and the one on arrhythmia was near-total. However, one additional document was added and several more possible additions came to light. Naturally, the comments on the availability of resources still apply. The Harcourt International journals site may well contain worthwhile material, but a subscription would be required in order to ascertain this. 
Two additional queries relate to the Bandolier Atrial Fibrillation site and the way in which PRODIGY documents should be catalogued.
